matched.expectedTitle: XML External Entity (XXE) Injection via SVG Upload
matched.actualTitle: XXE (XML External Entity) Injection via SVG File Upload - Arbitrary File Read
matched.matchReason: Perfect match - The expected XXE vulnerability via SVG upload was discovered. The actual finding confirms the unsafe XML parser configuration (lxml with load_dtd=True and resolve_entities=True) enables XXE attacks. The POC successfully extracted /etc/passwd file content, demonstrating the server-side file read impact exactly as described in the expected finding.

matched.actualTitle: Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via SVG File Upload and Stored XSS via SVG File Upload with Event Handlers
matched.matchReason: Strong match - The expected arbitrary SVG upload vulnerability was discovered with multiple exploitation vectors. The actual findings demonstrate that SVG files without proper content validation are stored and rendered, enabling both stored XSS via script tags and event handler execution (onload, onerror). This confirms the unrestricted upload and lack of sanitization described in the expected finding.

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Profile Update Form
extra.location: Profile update endpoint at root path (/)
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application completely lacks CSRF token validation on state-changing POST requests. This is a distinct vulnerability from the upload issues, allowing attackers to modify user profiles from external sites. Severity: HIGH as it enables unauthorized data modification.

extra.title: Missing Authentication on Profile Update Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The profile update endpoint accepts unauthenticated requests without any authentication validation. Combined with missing CSRF protection, this allows completely unauthorized profile modifications. Severity: HIGH as it violates fundamental access control principles.

extra.title: XXE Billion Laughs DoS (XML Bomb) Attack via SVG Entity Expansion
extra.assessment: New discovery - The XXE vulnerability extends to billion laughs/XML bomb DoS attacks through recursive entity expansion. The malicious SVG with nested entity definitions expands exponentially (10,000x factor) causing resource exhaustion. Severity: HIGH as it enables denial of service.

extra.title: HTTP Method Confusion - Allow Header Mismatch and Method Override
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application advertises only GET method via Allow header but accepts POST requests and supports method override techniques (X-HTTP-Method-Override, _method parameter). This enables bypassing intended method restrictions. Severity: HIGH for potential access control bypass.

extra.title: Excessive HTTP Method Override Support - Multiple Vectors
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application supports 9 different method override mechanisms (5 headers + 4 query parameters), dramatically increasing attack surface. This excessive support makes it impractical to secure all bypass vectors. Severity: HIGH for increased attack surface.

extra.title: Case-Insensitive HTTP Method Override Parsing - WAF Bypass
extra.assessment: New discovery - HTTP method override headers and values are parsed case-insensitively, allowing attackers to bypass WAF rules designed with case-sensitive pattern matching. This enables circumventing security controls. Severity: HIGH for WAF bypass capability.

extra.title: File Type Validation Bypass - Non-SVG XML Files Accepted and Processed
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application accepts any XML-formatted file (.txt, .xml, etc.) and processes them as SVG, bypassing extension-based filtering. This allows XXE payloads to be delivered with innocuous file extensions. Severity: MEDIUM as it reduces effectiveness of network-level defenses.

extra.title: Denial of Service via Large Request Payload
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /ping endpoint terminates connections when requests exceed ~127KB payload, causing ChunkedEncodingError. Multiple concurrent large requests exhaust server resources. Severity: HIGH as it enables service unavailability.

extra.title: Server Information Disclosure via Server Header
extra.assessment: New discovery - The 'Server: uvicorn' header discloses that the backend uses Python ASGI, enabling targeted reconnaissance. Severity: LOW as it aids reconnaissance but isn't immediately exploitable.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - All 7 critical security headers are missing: X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, X-XSS-Protection, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy. Reduces defense-in-depth. Severity: LOW but demonstrates security best practice failures.

extra.title: Missing Cache-Control Headers on /ping Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /ping healthcheck endpoint lacks cache control headers, allowing intermediate proxies to cache stale health status. Severity: LOW but could cause load balancer confusion.

extra.title: Complete API Exposed Without Authentication in OpenAPI Specification
extra.assessment: New discovery - The entire API specification is publicly accessible without authentication, exposing complete attack surface including all endpoints, schemas, and confirming no security schemes are defined. Severity: CRITICAL as it eliminates reconnaissance time for attackers.

extra.title: Verbose Validation Error Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - The API returns detailed validation errors including field names, locations, and error types, allowing attackers to map the API schema through error responses. Severity: MEDIUM as it aids reconnaissance and parameter discovery.

extra.title: Information Disclosure: Unauthenticated Directory Listing Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /hint endpoint is an unauthenticated directory listing interface accepting user-controlled path parameters, potentially enabling directory traversal attacks. Severity: MEDIUM for information disclosure and traversal risk.

extra.title: XXE-based Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) - Potential Internal Service Access via XXE Protocol Bypass
extra.assessment: New discovery - The XXE vulnerability extends to SSRF attacks through protocol flexibility. While HTTP filtering exists at application level, the parser accepts multiple protocols (gopher://, dict://, ftp://) without restriction, enabling internal service reconnaissance. Severity: HIGH for potential SSRF capability.
